Multi-hydroxyl POSS supported iridium complexes as a recyclable catalyst for selective synthesis of N-/C-substituted indoles and the total synthesis of HIV-1 fusion inhibitor Jiahao Li a Li Chen a Likui Wang a Gang Shi a Dawei Wang a b ⁎ a Key Laboratory of Synthetic and Biological Colloids, Ministry of Education, School of Chemical and Material Engineering, Jiangnan University, Wuxi 214122, PR China Key Laboratory of Synthetic and Biological Colloids Ministry of Education School of Chemical and Material Engineering Jiangnan University Wuxi 214122 PR China Key Laboratory of Synthetic and Biological Colloids, Ministry of Education, School of Chemical and Material Engineering, Jiangnan University, Wuxi 214122, PR China b Shanghai Institute of Organic Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai 200032, PR China Shanghai Institute of Organic Chemistry Chinese Academy of Sciences Shanghai 200032 PR China Shanghai Institute of Organic Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai 200032, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author at: Key Laboratory of Synthetic and Biological Colloids, Ministry of Education, School of Chemical and Material Engineering, Jiangnan University, Wuxi 214122, PR China. Key Laboratory of Synthetic and Biological Colloids Ministry of Education School of Chemical and Material Engineering Jiangnan University Wuxi 214122 PR China Graphical abstract A novel pyridyl-thiadiazole ligand has been designed, synthesized, and employed in the preparation of a heterogeneous iridium catalyst supported on multi-hydroxyl polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane. The as-prepared catalyst exhibits excellent catalytic activity in the one-pot cascade selective synthesis of N-/C-substituted indole derivatives from amino alcohols and alcohols via borrowing hydrogen strategy. Meanwhile, it was observed that this approach has a good functional group tolerance and broad substrate scope. Notably, by employing this catalytic system, an inhibitor against gp41-mediated HIV-1 fusion core structure could be conveniently synthesized from 2-aminophenethyl alcohol derivatives and benzyl alcohols in 41 % total yield for only four steps via “borrowing hydrogen” strategy. Mechanistic explorations showed that this transformation undergoes cascade processes, involving N/C-alkylation through borrowing hydrogen strategy, and oxidative cyclization. Recycling experiments disclosed that the catalyst could be easily recovered and reused for at least seven times with good TON. Keywords N-/C-substituted indoles HIV-1 fusion inhibitor Alcohols Selective synthesis Supported iridium catalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Indoles are a class of heterocycles frequently present in various bioactive natural products and agrochemicals as well as pharmaceutical ingredients having a diverse range of structural and broad biological activities (Scheme 1 ) [1]. Due to the prevalence of substituted indoles, the development of new synthetic methods for the selective synthesis of functionalized indoles continues to be a hot field of research [2]. The traditional methods for the synthesis of C-alkylation of indoles is the Friedel-Crafts reaction with haloalkanes, which needs numerous Lewis acid [3]. However, the selective synthesis of N/C-alkylation of indoles is quite more difficult, particularly in one reaction system [4]. Traditionally, the N-alkylation of indoles was synthesized by the reaction of indole with alkyl halide, which are not in accord with the development concept of green chemistry [5]. Compared to conventional synthetic approaches (Scheme 2 ), the method for the synthesis of substituted indoles employing alcohols as alkylating reagents through borrowing hydrogen strategy are more competitive [6–7]. Water is the only byproduct in borrowing hydrogen reactions and has high atomic efficiency [8–9]. As for the C-alkylation of indoles with alcohols, which was first reported by Grigg and co-workers using homogeneous Ir catalyst to obtain C-alkylated indoles in 2007 [10]. Later, several reports on the C-alkylation of indoles were presented with homogeneous Rh [11], Ru [12], Ni [13], Cu [14], Fe [15], Mn [16] catalysts. In 2013, Shimizu group developed the first heterogeneous Pt/Al2O3 catalyst to catalyze regioselective C-alkylated indoles [17]. Recently, Beller and co-workers reported a heterogeneous cobalt catalyst for C-alkylation of indoles by using straightforward borrowing hydrogen methodology. This protocol exhibited good functional group tolerance and delivered a class of bioactive heterocyclic compounds in good to excellent yields [18]. However, all of the above excellent explorations were made by the reaction of prefabricated indoles with alcohols as reactants to obtain C-alkylation of indoles. In 2020, Adhikari et al expanded Ni-catalyzed C-alkylated indoles, which use 2-aminophenethyl alcohol instead of indole as the reactant [19]. In contrast, the synthesis of N-alkylated indoles with alcohols has been rarely reported. In 2010, Beller, Williams and coworkers was first reported the synthesis of N-alkylated indoles via a Ru-Shvo catalyst with a Brønsted acidic co-catalyst [20]. Shi group found that heterogeneous Fe2O3/Pd catalyst realized the synthesis of N-alkylation of indole with alcohol but only one example of the substrate scope [21]. Besides, Shimizu and co-workers described an efficient Pt/HBEA catalyst for the selective synthesis of N-alkylated indoles through the borrowing hydrogen strategy [22]. Similarly, prefabricated indoles were used as starting materials to obtain desired products in all the above explorations. Very recently, Balaraman and co-workers reported catalytic N-alkylation of indoles using 2-aminophenethyl alcohol as reactant by homogeneous Ni catalyst [23]. All these reported methods are based on alcohols as alkylating reagents through borrowing hydrogen strategy [24]. Despite the tremendous achievement, in view of the concerns about sustainable development and green chemistry, the development of an innovative heterogeneous catalyst for the synthesis of C- and N-substituted indoles is still highly desirable [25]. During the past, our group mainly developed several new typical catalysts based on triazole or nitrogen-containing heterocycles skeleton ligands, which could catalyze lots of common dehydrogenation and borrowing hydrogen reactions [26]. However, most of these catalysts usually revealed poor reactivity, stability and reusability in most cases [27]. Herein, we designed and synthesized a novel nitrogen-containing pyridyl-thiadiazole (PTA) ligand and immobilized it with multi-hydroxyl polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane (OH-POSS) through silane coupling agent. After treatment with iridium, this heterogeneous catalyst PTA-Ir@POSS has synthesized and used for the synthesis of substituted indole derivatives. Interestingly, starting from 2-aminophenylethanol and benzyl alcohols, two different products of C- and N-alkylation of indoles can be selectively obtained by base regulation. As far as we know, this is the first example to obtain C- and N-alkylation of indoles with high selectivity from 2-aminophenylethanol by using heterogeneous catalysts through borrowing hydrogen strategy. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 The synthesis of PTA-Ir@POSS As depicted in Scheme 3 , pyridyl-thiadiazole (PTA) ligand (1b) was prepared through a two-step process. Primarily, the mixture of thiosemicarbazide and CS2 was dissolved and reacted in DMF at reflux for 4 h to afford 2-amino-5-mercapto-1,3,4-thiadiazole (1a). Then, the purified 1a and 2-iodopyridine, as well as the required additives, were stirred in DMF for 10 h, affording PTA ligand (1b). Subsequently, 1c was obtained in 95 % yield from the reaction between amino- and isocyanate-group, leading to coupling-functionalized ligand. Multi-hydroxyl POSS (OH-POSS) was successfully synthesized via thiol-ene click reaction between octavinyl POSS (OVPOSS) and 1-thioglycerol in the presence of AIBN as initiator. With 1c and OH-POSS in hand, through hydrolysis of -Si(OEt)3 in 1c and further condensation with –OH on the surface of OH-POSS, surface-modified PTA-POSS were formed and subsequent metalation. More detailed experimental steps were described in supporting information. 2.2 Characterization of the PTA-Ir@POSS After synthesis, PTA-Ir@POSS was carefully characterized via Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR), Energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS), Scanning electron microscope (SEM), Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray photoelectron spectrometry (XPS). Firstly, the chemical structures of PTA, OH-POSS and PTA-Ir@POSS were confirmed by FT-IR (Fig. 1 a.). The IR spectra of PTA showed bands at 3283 cm−1 assigned to stretching vibrations of NH groups, 1594 cm−1 due to CN of the pyridine and thiadiazol skeleton. Besides, we can observe characteristic peaks at 3400 and 1088 cm−1 which are attributed to the stretching vibrations of OH and SiO bonds on the support of OH-POSS, respectively. For the spectrum of PTA-Ir@POSS, the characteristic peaks observed at 3401, 1684 and 1590 cm−1 are attributed to the presence of OH, CO and CN groups on the PTA-Ir@POSS, the intensity of the fundamental vibrations for pyridine ring (1300–1600 cm−1) in PTA-Ir@POSS obviously decreased as compared with that of PTA, which revealed that the iridium species were immobilized through abundant N atoms in ligand PTA [28]. Meanwhile, a new peak appearing at 1107 cm−1 could be assigned to the stretching vibrations of SiO bonds. The above results indicate that PTA-Ir complex have been successfully covalently grafted onto the support of OH-POSS. The compositional distribution of the PTA-Ir@POSS were investigated by EDS (Fig. 1b). EDS pattern showed peaks at 2.0 and 9.2 keV, which were characteristic peaks of iridium, which also disclosed that PTA-Ir was supported on OH-POSS successfully. In addition, the morphology of PTA-Ir@POSS was examined by SEM and TEM. The SEM images of PTA-Ir@POSS (Fig. 2 a and 2b) show that the catalyst exhibits an irregular blocky structure. Notably, the presence of rough surfaces was attached with an amorphous connected particle. The TEM and HRTEM images of the obtained catalyst are given in (Fig. 2c-2f). The HRTEM images demonstrate that PTA-Ir complex have been successfully embedded in OH-POSS. In the final PTA-Ir@POSS composite, small Ir particles are uniformly distributed on PTA-Ir@POSS without visible aggregation. The lattice plane distance of 0.275 nm is consistent with the lattice plane of iridium species. The HAADF-STEM EDS elemental mapping images of PTA-Ir@POSS showed that C, N, Ir, and O elements are homogeneously distributed on the entire material (Fig. 2g). To explore the surface chemical states and chemical composition of PTA-Ir@POSS, XPS was carried out (Fig. 3 .). As shown in Fig. 3a. The XPS survey spectrum of PTA-Ir@POSS clearly showed the presence of C, N, O, Si, S, Cl and Ir elements. The XPS high-resolution C 1s spectrum of the catalyst (Fig. 3b) showed five peaks at 284.3, 284.8, 285.5, 286.5 and 288.9 eV, representing the carbon bonds of C-Si; C–C/CC; C-N/C-S; C–O, and CO, respectively [29]. In the N 1s spectrum (Fig. 3c) exhibited three types of nitrogen environments, which can be attributed to pyridinic-N (398.6 ev), coordinated-N (399.4 eV), and pyrrolic-N (400.4 eV) [30]. Moreover, the Ir 4f7/2 and 4f5/2 peaks are observed at 62.8 and 65.8 eV respectively (Fig. 3d.). The doublet at 62.3 eV and 65.3 eV were accordance with the reported data for Ir 4f7/2 and Ir 4f5/2 of IrIII, providing further evidence that PTA-Ir has been successfully loaded onto the OH-POSS material [31]. The Ir content in PTA-Ir@POSS was examined to be 2.2 wt% based on the ICP-AES result. 2.3 Catalytic activity With PTA-Ir@POSS in hand, we studied the model reaction using 2-aminophenethyl alcohol (2a) with benzyl alcohols (3a) to implement an efficient catalytic system for indole derivatives synthesis. Primarily, four different equiv. of Cs2CO3 were employed involving PTA-Ir@POSS as catalyst of our choice (Table 1 , entries 1–4). Initial trials using 0.2 equiv. of Cs2CO3 gave a mixture of N- and C-alkylated indoles. However, at higher base concentration the reaction was highly selective for N-alkylated indole (4a), which was isolated in 94 % yield with a TON of up to 3404. (Table 1, entry 4). Next, we tried using KOH as a base, it was disclosed that with the increase of KOH concentration, the selectivity of C-alkylated indole increased greatly. We observed 85 % isolated yield of 5aa involving a combination of 5.0 mg (0.028 mol%, Ir 2.2 % loading, w/w) PTA-Ir@POSS with 2.0 equiv. of KOH in toluene at 120 °C (Table 1, entries 8). Furthermore, using different solvents like DMF, 1,4-dioxane, H2O, DMA and p-xylene, which proved inefficient for the synthesis of N-alkylated indole (4a) (entries 1–5, Table S1). Whereas, in the case of p-xylene we observed moderate C3-alkylated indole product (5aa) conversion (entry 10 Table S1). With the optimization of reaction conditions in hand, the substrate expansion for the reaction of 2-aminophenethyl alcohol with benzyl alcohols was examined with PTA-Ir@POSS as the catalyst (Table 2 ). A series of benzyl alcohols bearing both electron-withdrawing and electron-donating groups were converted to the desired N-alkylated indoles products with moderate to good isolated yields (71–94 %). It could be found that benzyl alcohols containing electron-donating groups can obtain higher yields than benzyl alcohols containing electron-withdrawing groups. Several ortho-substituted benzyl alcohols ranging from –F, –Cl, -Br, -CF3 to –Me offered the respective desired products with 78–87 % yields (4 g, 4j, 4 m, 4p, 4b). The meta-substituted benzyl alcohols were also separated the corresponding indoles successfully with moderate yields (4c, 4e, 4 h, 4 k, 4n, 4q). Specifically, those para-substituted benzyl alcohols resulted in the corresponding N-alkylated indoles in higher yields compared with meta- and ortho-substituted benzyl alcohols which probably due to the steric hindrance. In addition, the yield wasn't reduced when the electronic effect was enhanced by adding substituents on the same aromatic ring (4v). Moreover, substrates with naphthalene groups could proceed smoothly and afford the desired products with good yields (4w, 4x). Subsequently, we next explored the range of substrates for the synthesis of C-alkylated indoles with PTA-Ir@POSS as catalyst (Table 3 ). To our delight, Various benzyl alcohols were utilized to give the target products in moderate to good yields (5aa-5ak). Notably, the alcohols with heterocyclic rings like thiophene and furan proceed smoothly and furnished 5am, 5an and 5ap in 76–81 % yields. However, only 58 % yield was obtained with heterocyclic alcohols as pyridine 5ao. In addition, substrates with naphthalene and biphenyl groups transformed into the desired products with moderate yields (5aq-5as). Considering such outstanding activities of this catalyst PTA-Ir@POSS, we explored PTA-Ir@POSS to the reaction between indoles and benzyl alcohols. As shown in Table 4 , a wide array of benzyl alcohols bearing both electron-donating and electron-withdrawing groups was used, resulting in C-alkylated indoles in good yields (77–92 %). Then we investigated the reaction of indole substituted by different substituents with benzyl alcohol. With either electron-rich or electron-poor indole as substrates, benzyl alcohol was completely converted into target products (5bb-5bl). To our delight, indole containing methyl in the 2-position could react with benzyl alcohol and generate the corresponding desired product in moderate yields (5ba). 2.4 Mechanism exploration In order to better explore the reaction mechanism of this transformation and the coordination environment between metal Ir and PTA ligand in the catalyst, iridium complex was synthesized in a straightforward approach by the reaction of ligand PTA and [Cp*IrCl2]2 in MeOH at 80 °C. The iridium complex PTA-Ir could be crystallized by slow diffusion of n-hexane into a concentrated solution of complexes in acetonitrile and afforded crystals. Then the exact structure of PTA-Ir determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (CCDC: 2142357), which indicated that the supposed structure was correct (Scheme 4 ). As depicted in Scheme 4, the inspection of the structure of Ir1 reveals the metal center to be surrounded by an NN-chelating PTA, a Cp* ligand and a chloride so as to complete an octahedral coordination geometry. The Ir–N2 (2.096 Å) bond length was relatively shorter compared to Ir–N1 (2.125 Å) in this complex, which suggested that the binding of the thiadiazole nitrogen was stronger than that of the pyridine nitrogen with the Ir-center. To better show the catalytic performance of PTA-Ir@POSS, the reaction of 2a and 3a was conducted compared with different metal salt catalysts. As shown in Scheme 5 , it was demonstrated that the PTA-Ir@POSS catalytic system has better performance superiority in the cases of yields and selectivity than other commercially available simple iridium salts catalyst systems. This advantage might be attributed to the synergistic effects of PTA-Ir complex and base together with the silane coupling agent, which enhanced the ligand–metal bonds and the stability of the catalyst. Meanwhile, the blank experiment suggested that only carrier or ligand could not promote this reaction. These experiments indicated that PTA-Ir@POSS has played an essential role during this transformation. To gain more insight for this heterogeneous PTA-Ir@POSS catalytic system on borrowing hydrogen reaction we explored the initial mechanistic studies for the process. Firstly, in this catalytic system the addition of 2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-1-piperidinyloxy (TEMPO) and butylated hydroxy toluene (BHT) radical scavengers to the reaction did not prevent the production of 4a, which discard the involvement of free-radical intermediates in the process (Scheme 6 a). Additionally, the blank experiment found that the reaction could not take place in the absence of base and catalyst. Moreover, the reaction showed poor yield and selectivity when there was only base but no PTA-Ir@POSS as catalyst in the reaction system, which prove their significant role for the dehydrogenative condensation to N-alkylated indoles synthesis (Scheme 6b). In addition, in order to clarify the effect of different substituents on the reactivity, some control experiments were carried out subsequently. Initial experiment disclosed that benzyl alcohols bearing electron-donating groups was preferentially consumed, which revealed that benzyl alcohols with electron-donating group was much more reactive than that with electron-withdrawing group for this transformation (Scheme 6c). Furthermore, a series of control experiments were performed. Initially, the independent reaction of 2a under our two standard conditions led to 92 % and 95 % of the indole (6a), respectively (Scheme 7 a). Next, we investigated the PTA-Ir@POSS and base catalyzed dehydrogenation of 3a. Under standard conditions, 3a converts benzaldehyde (3a’) in 48 % and 52 % isolated yield, respectively (Scheme 7b). Interestingly, the condensation of 6a and 3a’ was found to be assisted by the base, which was confirmed that base plays a key role for condensation (Scheme 7c). Notably, in the presence of PTA-Ir@POSS, the reaction of intermediate α,β-unsaturated imine (13) and 2a also proceed well, producing the corresponding C-alkylation of indole (5aa) in excellent yields (Scheme 7d). All these results provide substantial evidence that PTA-Ir@POSS acts a critical role for deprotonation of alcohols and reduction, and the reaction of 2a and 3a provided C-alkylation of indole follows a standard borrowing hydrogen protocol. However, using Cs2CO3 as a base, the 4a was obtained in trace (Scheme 7e), and 5aa was identified as the unique product of this reaction. This result aforementioned support that 6a is not an intermediate for the synthesis of N-alkylated indole through the reaction of 2a and 3a. Additionally, in the presence of PTA-Ir@POSS, the N-alkylation product 2-(2-(benzylamino)-phenyl)ethanol (14) was observed in 95 % yield from the reaction of 2a and 3a in the initial stage of the reaction (Scheme 7f). Thus, the synthesis of 6a and 14 from 2a is a competitive reaction in beginning. Finally, the reaction of 14 failed to provide 4a (low yields) in the absence of 2a or alcohols, while the same reaction in the presence of 2a provided the product 4a in a good yield of 93 % (Scheme 7g). These experiments disclosed that the possible reaction pathway and mechanism for the synthesis of N-alkylated indole derivatives. In order to know the effect of cesium ion and carbonate ion on this reaction process, several control experiments were conducted subsequently (Scheme 8 ). Initially, different cesium salts were screened for the reaction of 2a with 3a using PTA-Ir@POSS as catalyst in toluene under 120 °C. Cs2CO3 was found to show the highest activity. In contrast, nearly no reaction took place by using CsCl or CsOAc as catalyst. However, when alkaline salts such as CsHCO3 and CsOH·H2O were used, the reaction could occur and furnished 4a with moderate yields respectively. When considering the influence of anions, Na2CO3, NaHCO3, Li2CO3 and K2CO3 were used as additive for this conversion. However, the results show that the desired product 4a was not obtained. The above results indicated that cesium ions might lead to the preferential N-alkylation of amino alcohols in the initial stage of the reaction, resulting in the formation of N-substituted indoles. According to the above-mentioned experiment results on intermediates and mechanism investigations and related literature [14,16,21], a plausible mechanism for the synthesis of N-/C-alkylated indoles is proposed in Scheme 9 . Initially, the deprotonation of 3a assisted by the Cs2CO3 to produce the active species, and then participate in the catalytic cycle. Then, PTA-Ir@POSS reacted with cesium alkoxide to give the alkoxy intermediate A, which underwent β-hydride elimination of alkoxide to provide the [Ir-H] species with the formation of dehydrogenated product 3a’. Subsequently, in the presence of base, 3a’ reacted with 2a to form imine intermediate B, followed by the reduction of B generated N-alkylation product 14 through the [Ir-H] species. Finally, the intermediate 14 underwent oxidative cyclization under the synergistic effect of PTA-Ir@POSS and Cs2CO3 to obtain the N-alkylated indoles 4a. 2.5 Reusability of the catalyst The reusability of heterogeneous catalysts is important for practical production. To evaluate the PTA-Ir@POSS recyclability, it is recovered by centrifugating, washing with methanol, water and ethanol, and drying under vacuum at 75 °C. The Ir concentration in the filtrate was calculated by ICP-MS in the first cycle, which was found to be less than 1.0 μg L−1. Even PTA-Ir@POSS was reused for seven cycles, affording 4a in 90 % yield, with a TON of 3259, indicating that PTA-Ir@POSS has a superior reusability (Fig. 4 ). In addition, the TEM images of the PTA-Ir@POSS used for seven cycles is presented in Fig. S2. The region with PTA-Ir complex was still observed, and the Ir species are still highly dispersed on POSS-OH. (Fig. S2a and S2b). Meanwhile, The HAADF-STEM EDS elemental mapping demonstrated that iridium was no conspicuous agglomeration was found after the recycling tests (Fig. S2c). Moreover, the catalyst PTA-Ir@POSS recovered from the seven cycle was analyzed by XPS. As shown in Fig. S3d high-resolution If 4f XPS of PTA-Ir@POSS, exhibiting the same binding energy as before. These results suggest that the good stability and the potential applicability of PTA-Ir@POSS. Finally, we performed gram-scale reactions and more than ten grams of desired products 4f, 5an and 5ae were isolated with PTA-Ir@POSS as a catalyst. It was revealed that this catalytic system was a much greener method for the selective synthesis N/C-alkylation of indoles starting from 2-aminophenethyl alcohol, which was accorded with the concept of environment friendly development(Scheme 10 ). N-alkylated indoles is of great value to industry. We therefore developed a synthetic route to selectively alkylate indole in the N-position to obtain a biologically active molecule 12, as inhibitor against gp41-mediated HIV-1 fusion, which was previously prepared by using strong base to deprotonate the NH bond to improve the nucleophilicity of nitrogen atoms, and then reacts with haloalkane [32]. In contrast, by employing this catalytic system, this core structure could be synthesized efficiently from 2-aminophenethyl alcohol derivatives and benzyl alcohols in 41 % total yield for only four steps via “borrowing hydrogen” strategy (Scheme 11 ). 3 Conclusions In conclusion, we have successfully developed an efficient and novel heterogeneous catalyst PTA-Ir@POSS by using a multi-hydroxyl POSS-immobilized iridium complex, which was characterized by FT-IR, SEM, TEM, EDS and XPS. In addition, we demonstrated the first heterogeneous catalyst that can efficient for one-pot cascade selective synthesis of N/C-alkylation of indoles starting from readily available 2-aminophenethyl alcohol. Interestingly, we have successfully achieved gram scale synthesis of an inhibitor against gp41-mediated HIV-1 fusion core structure with good yield by using this catalyst. Meanwhile, the PTA-Ir@POSS exhibits excellent activities and good reusability for this transformation. Furthermore, preliminary mechanistic investigations were performed to figure out the possible reaction mechanism. This catalytic system was an environmentally benign and highly atom-economical strategy for the synthesis of indole derivatives, which provided a new idea for organic synthesis catalysis. coredata.dc:description: A novel pyridyl-thiadiazole ligand has been designed, synthesized, and employed in the preparation of a heterogeneous iridium catalyst supported on multi-hydroxyl polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane. The as-prepared catalyst exhibits excellent catalytic activity in the one-pot cascade selective synthesis of N-/C-substituted indole derivatives from amino alcohols and alcohols via borrowing hydrogen strategy. Meanwhile, it was observed that this approach has a good functional group tolerance and broad substrate scope. Notably, by employing this catalytic system, an inhibitor against gp41-mediated HIV-1 fusion core structure could be conveniently synthesized from 2-aminophenethyl alcohol derivatives and benzyl alcohols in 41 % total yield for only four steps via “borrowing hydrogen” strategy. Mechanistic explorations showed that this transformation undergoes cascade processes, involving N/C-alkylation through borrowing hydrogen strategy, and oxidative cyclization. Recycling experiments disclosed that the catalyst could be easily recovered and reused for at least seven times with good TON.
coredata.dc:title: Multi-hydroxyl POSS supported iridium complexes as a recyclable catalyst for selective synthesis of N-/C-substituted indoles and the total synthesis of HIV-1 fusion inhibitor
